topic.title: HPE Helion OpenStack 1.0: Updating the Undercloud

body.p: Use the this document when updating the undercloud nodes.
You can monitor the update process, see Monitoring the Update.

section.title: Prerequisites

li.p: If the seed VM needed updating, perform this update before updating the undercloud, as described in Updating the Seed Cloud Host.
Copy the TAR file to the seed cloud host and extract contents. From an SSH session to the seed cloud host do the following:

codeblock.codeph:
ssh root@<seed_cloud_host_IP> scp heat-admin@<undercloud_IP>:/tmp/heat_templates/* /tmp
tar xvf tripleo-ansible<version>.tar mv /opt/stack/tripleo-ansible /opt/stack/tripleo-ansible-orig mv /tmp/tripleo-ansible /opt/stack/

li.p: Where:

ul.li: <Insert undercloudIP> is the IP of the undercloud node
/tmp/heat_templates/ is the default location of the TAR files; enter the appropriate location, if you changed the location.

section.p: The files extracted in the seed tmp node. If desired, you can delete the files in the /tmp/heat_templates directory.

section.title: Change the default
section.p: It is possible to change the location of the undercloud patch update TAR files, during or after deployment. The default location is the /tmp/heat_templates folder.
If you have done so you can recall where you have changed the directory to by viewing the Sherpa configuration file.
The Sherpa configuration file for the undercloud can be found at /etc/sherpa/sherpa.conf.
The directory where the files where stored can be found by looking in the RepositoryMgr portion of /etc/sherpa/sherpa.conf. Search for the directory attribute as seen below:
When locating the update files, use the directory set in /etc/sherpa/sherpa.conf.

li.p: Review the update prerequisites and make sure all necessary tasks have been performed. .
Backup a copy of the undercloud to restore in case of catastrophic failures. For information, see Back Up and Restore.
Make sure that you have a least 7GB of space available on the seed node. Converting to the raw mode will take space on the seed.

Point the install script to the undercloud. The patch update script is based on the Ansible platform. For the undercloud, because the script is launched from the seed cloud host, you need to point the script to the seed cloud host.
To point the script to update the undercloud, use the following steps:
a. Login to seed
b. Run the following command
c. Execute the following commands:

codeblock.codeph: source /opt/stack/venvs/ansible/bin/activate cd /opt/stack/tripleo-ansible bash scripts/inject_nova_meta.bash export ANSIBLE_LOG_PATH=/var/log/ansible/ansible.log mkdir -p /var/log/ansible

li.p: The command prompt should change to (ansible). You must use (ansible) session for executing all the update operations manually.
d. To test that the ansible environment is correctly setup, use the following command to ping all the nodes that ansible can find via its inventory:
If successful, the ping command will show a ping of every node in a particular cloud. It will look similar to this with one for each node.

section.title: Update the undercloud manually
section.p: The manual method generally gives you more control of the update.

There are three images that you need to place into the seed glance for the Undercloud. These images will be delivered in a file called undercloud.tar and are located in the undercloud local filesystem after you obtain and extract the update package.
Please refer to Extract the required scripts and libraries in Update Prerequisites for instructions on locating the directory the undercloud.tar.
To update a node, the patch image needs to be loaded into the seed VM Image Operations service (Glance). A qcow2 image used for image update has dependencies on vmlinuz and initrd images.
Use the following steps to load upload an image and its dependencies:

li.p: Copy the new undercloud images into the seed glance repo.
SSH to the seed VM as root:
Run the update do the following:
Rename the old undercloud image using the following commands

codeblock.codeph:
export IMAGE_ID='glance image-list | grep undercloud | grep qcow2 | awk '{print $2}'' export RAMDISK_ID='glance image-list | grep undercloud-initrd | awk '{print $2}'' export KERNEL_ID='glance image-list | grep undercloud-vmlinuz | awk '{print $2}''
glance image-update --name undercloud-old $IMAGE_ID glance image-update --name undercloud-initrd-old $RAMDISK_ID glance image-update --name undercloud-vmlinuz-old $KERNEL_ID

li.p: Upload new undercloud images to glance

codeblock.codeph:
glance image-create --is-public True --is-protected False --name undercloud.vmlinuz --file undercloud.vmlinuz --disk-format aki --container-format aki
glance image-create --is-public True --is-protected False --name undercloud.initrd --file undercloud.initrd --disk-format ari --container-format ari
glance image-create --name <image name> --disk-format qcow2 --container-format bare --is-public True --file patch1.qcow2 --property ramdisk_id=<GlanceId of initrd image> --property kernel_id=<GlanceId of vmlinuz image

li.p: Make sure you are in the /opt/stack/tripleo-ansible directory and that you have the (ansbile) as part of your command prompt.
Run the following command:

codeblock.codeph: ansible-playbook -vvvv -u heat-admin -i plugins/inventory/heat.py -e force_rebuild=True -l <IP of undercloud> -e undercloud_rebuild_image_id=<glance Image_ID of undercloud> playbooks/update_cloud.yml

li.p: Ansible will show progress and alert you to failures. The -vvvv option makes information available in case of failure.
When the update is done, validate the update.

section.title: Validate the update
section.p: Verify that services and communication between nodes is functional.

Log in:
Run the following commands to make sure all systems appear as expected:

codeblock.codeph: #. stackrc - to source the credentials or setup credentials nova list heat stack-list glance image-list

li.p: Launch the Horizon UI and make sure you can authenticate successfully.

section.title: Backup the updated undercloud
section.p: Once the update of undercloud node is complete, you should backup the node in case of failures. See Back Up and Restore.
